div.p: Greetings. I received your letter, most esteemed and beloved brother in the Lord, along with 4 kisses. As for what to say about that Dodonean money, I do not know; it is indeed strange if his wife left so much money to our hospital as he claims to have left upon dying; for he has testified to me once and again that they are poorer than church mice. Therefore, I have no doubt that he is spreading lies, and this is the gratitude he shows to our most honorable magistrate, although I have not yet discussed this matter with the master of the hospital. You will understand what I have done with Mr. Burcher and what I have achieved from his letters.

The Bishop of Salisbury writes from England that the state of religion is well, thanks to God. However, I understand that a serious war is about to break out there, as the English join with the Scots, and in a certain battle, the Scots defeated the French with the help of English soldiers. The Lutherans are not only raging against us in a strange manner, but they are also completely furious. I cannot say more now.
Farewell and write back when you have time.
From France, I fear we will not hear any good news.
We must pray to the Lord to heal the aggravated matters and preserve His church. Meanwhile, farewell with all your family.
When you recently wrote through Mr. Hegner, I was in the countryside; otherwise, I would have most gladly and faithfully offered you my services. I returned the next day, when he had already left.
I wish to know what you have accomplished.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Ambrosius Blarer, residing in Winterthur, his esteemed lord and dearest brother. Winterthur.
